body:
EDIT: I don't use grub, I use either UEFI or BIOS, I think its bios.

EDIT 2: I checked the other boot options, all 3 of them just bring me to the same thing, the grub bootloader, where I have fedora, fedora advanced (safemode), Ubuntu, Ubuntu avanced (safemode), and 1 of them brings me to an efi shell for my motherboard.

I installed Fedora 33 today, and it worked perfectly! Only problem is that none of my other os's boot up now. to boot i use my motherboard's boot thingy. I had kubuntu and windows installed, but now none of them show up. they're not deleted, I checked, the files are still there, but they won't start. they're all on the same drive, split up by partitions. does anyone know how to fix this?? thank you
body_html:

body: Fedora probably replaced the bootloader during the installation, and it wouldn't know to re-add the other OS options to it from the old one. You'll have to do that yourself.
body_html: Fedora probably replaced the bootloader during the installation, and it wouldn't know to re-add the other OS options to it from the old one. You'll have to do that yourself.

body:
If you’re using grub2 as a boot loader, try running:

sudo update-grub

Edit: never mind,  that’s an ubuntu only script. Look here for more help, I’m not too familiar with fedora:

https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/GRUB_2#Create_a_GRUB_2_configuration
body_html:
If you’re using grub2 as a boot loader, try running:

Edit: never mind, that’s an ubuntu only script. Look here for more help, I’m not too familiar with fedora:

https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/GRUB_2#Create_a_GRUB_2_configuration

body: I'll be honest I have no idea, since the only bootloader I've ever installed manually was for arch, and even then it ran an automatic script. But it probably doesn't matter, since every bootloader is different. Is there an option under your OS list that says choose something else? If not what about a settings option? Otherwise find out which bootloader you have and then search for how to add your older OSes to it.
body_html: I'll be honest I have no idea, since the only bootloader I've ever installed manually was for arch, and even then it ran an automatic script. But it probably doesn't matter, since every bootloader is different. Is there an option under your OS list that says choose something else? If not what about a settings option? Otherwise find out which bootloader you have and then search for how to add your older OSes to it.

body:
Quick fix is to disable UEFI Secure Boot in the BIOS and reinstall with an MBR installation, then edit the bootloader menu file and update it. Grub 2 is the most likely bootloader for this since you were already booting Windows and Ubuntu.

You may have wanted to disable fast boot in Windows 10 as well. 

There seems to be a problem with ASRock's UEFI bootloader for dual booting to Linux OSs.

Prior to changing anything, I suggest backing up your current drive image using Clonezilla. This will take a lot of storage space on an external drive or second internal drive, and will take a long time. You could also clone the entire drive onto a blank drive of the same type,and this will take less time, but will take more space, and as stated it would require a drive of the same type.

At least back up all of your important data if you don't have the requisite storage to create a cloned drive or drive image.

You may try method 7 here. https://appuals.com/partition-configure-drives-linux-uefi-boot/

More reference. https://www.zdnet.com/article/installing-linux-on-a-pc-with-uefi-firmware-a-refresher/

If you are successfully getting in to Fedora, check the text of /boot/grub2/grub.cfg and post it here.
body_html:
Quick fix is to disable UEFI Secure Boot in the BIOS and reinstall with an MBR installation, then edit the bootloader menu file and update it. Grub 2 is the most likely bootloader for this since you were already booting Windows and Ubuntu.

You may have wanted to disable fast boot in Windows 10 as well.

There seems to be a problem with ASRock's UEFI bootloader for dual booting to Linux OSs.

Prior to changing anything, I suggest backing up your current drive image using Clonezilla. This will take a lot of storage space on an external drive or second internal drive, and will take a long time. You could also clone the entire drive onto a blank drive of the same type,and this will take less time, but will take more space, and as stated it would require a drive of the same type.

At least back up all of your important data if you don't have the requisite storage to create a cloned drive or drive image.

You may try method 7 here. https://appuals.com/partition-configure-drives-linux-uefi-boot/

More reference. https://www.zdnet.com/article/installing-linux-on-a-pc-with-uefi-firmware-a-refresher/

If you are successfully getting in to Fedora, check the text of /boot/grub2/grub.cfg and post it here.

post.body:
EDIT: I don't use grub, I use either UEFI or BIOS, I think its bios.

EDIT 2: I checked the other boot options, all 3 of them just bring me to the same thing, the grub bootloader, where I have fedora, fedora advanced (safemode), Ubuntu, Ubuntu avanced (safemode), and 1 of them brings me to an efi shell for my motherboard.

I installed Fedora 33 today, and it worked perfectly! Only problem is that none of my other os's boot up now. to boot i use my motherboard's boot thingy. I had kubuntu and windows installed, but now none of them show up. they're not deleted, I checked, the files are still there, but they won't start. they're all on the same drive, split up by partitions. does anyone know how to fix this?? thank you

author.bio: So you decided to click on my name.

body:
Im not gonna paste the whole thing, incase there is something that i shouldnt show (im not sure), but i did find something about windows boot manager! I've also replaced, what i think is, the uuid. Something that I noticed was that; windows was in grub.d/30, while the linux distros were in grub.d/10. I also noticed that the UUID was different than the one that fedora and ubuntu were using. I've also changed up the windows id in this paste.

https://pastebin.com/z46xMKqp
body_html:
Im not gonna paste the whole thing, incase there is something that i shouldnt show (im not sure), but i did find something about windows boot manager! I've also replaced, what i think is, the uuid. Something that I noticed was that; windows was in grub.d/30, while the linux distros were in grub.d/10. I also noticed that the UUID was different than the one that fedora and ubuntu were using. I've also changed up the windows id in this paste.

https://pastebin.com/z46xMKqp

guild.description: All about the Linux operating system.
guild.name: Linux

parent.body:
Quick fix is to disable UEFI Secure Boot in the BIOS and reinstall with an MBR installation, then edit the bootloader menu file and update it. Grub 2 is the most likely bootloader for this since you were already booting Windows and Ubuntu.

You may have wanted to disable fast boot in Windows 10 as well. 

There seems to be a problem with ASRock's UEFI bootloader for dual booting to Linux OSs.

Prior to changing anything, I suggest backing up your current drive image using Clonezilla. This will take a lot of storage space on an external drive or second internal drive, and will take a long time. You could also clone the entire drive onto a blank drive of the same type,and this will take less time, but will take more space, and as stated it would require a drive of the same type.

At least back up all of your important data if you don't have the requisite storage to create a cloned drive or drive image.

You may try method 7 here. https://appuals.com/partition-configure-drives-linux-uefi-boot/

More reference. https://www.zdnet.com/article/installing-linux-on-a-pc-with-uefi-firmware-a-refresher/

If you are successfully getting in to Fedora, check the text of /boot/grub2/grub.cfg and post it here.
parent.body_html:
Quick fix is to disable UEFI Secure Boot in the BIOS and reinstall with an MBR installation, then edit the bootloader menu file and update it. Grub 2 is the most likely bootloader for this since you were already booting Windows and Ubuntu.

You may have wanted to disable fast boot in Windows 10 as well.

There seems to be a problem with ASRock's UEFI bootloader for dual booting to Linux OSs.

Prior to changing anything, I suggest backing up your current drive image using Clonezilla. This will take a lot of storage space on an external drive or second internal drive, and will take a long time. You could also clone the entire drive onto a blank drive of the same type,and this will take less time, but will take more space, and as stated it would require a drive of the same type.

At least back up all of your important data if you don't have the requisite storage to create a cloned drive or drive image.

You may try method 7 here. https://appuals.com/partition-configure-drives-linux-uefi-boot/

More reference. https://www.zdnet.com/article/installing-linux-on-a-pc-with-uefi-firmware-a-refresher/

If you are successfully getting in to Fedora, check the text of /boot/grub2/grub.cfg and post it here.

body:
#### I HAVE AN IDEA!

It's Fedora that overwrote your bootloader, right?

And dualbooting with Windows and Kubuntu worked just fine, right?

Well, try reinstalling just Kubuntu! Maybe reinstalling the bootloader by reinstalling Kubuntu will overwrite the bootlaoder and find the other boot entries!

And, of course, back up your important documents prior to this. Clonezilla is also a great idea if you have a secondary storage device with enough space for the OSs that worked.
body_html:

And, of course, back up your important documents prior to this. Clonezilla is also a great idea if you have a secondary storage device with enough space for the OSs that worked.

body:
Keep it! Kubuntu's bootloader may just recognize Fedora's.

From what I've read not only does ASRocks have problems with the bootloader in their firmware for both Linux and MacOS/OS X installations, but Fedora has it's own bootloader problems since version 30.

If Kubuntu worked for itself and Windows it just may work for Fedora as well.
body_html:
Keep it! Kubuntu's bootloader may just recognize Fedora's.

From what I've read not only does ASRocks have problems with the bootloader in their firmware for both Linux and MacOS/OS X installations, but Fedora has it's own bootloader problems since version 30.

If Kubuntu worked for itself and Windows it just may work for Fedora as well.

author.bio: So you decided to click on my name.
author.bio_html: So you decided to click on my name.

body:
IT WORKED!! But not like how you expected it to.

While in fedora, I uninstalled kubuntu. I didn't reinstall it, I just deleted it. but then I wondered if it would still show up in the bootloader. so I rebooted, and instead of it going to the grub bootloader, it went straight to windows! Didn't even have to reinstall it. I think the grub bootloader might have already been on kubuntu, and fedora recognized that, so it just added itself to it. so when it was deleted, the bootloader was too. now windows will boot! thank you so much, without you I wouldn't have been able to do this without you.

edit: now that I look at it, fedora was also deleted. not the os, but the bootloader was kind of necessary for it to open. I'm gonna reinstall kubuntu, and not mess with fedora again until I'm dedicating my computer to Linux.

Thank you! 💜
body_html:
IT WORKED!! But not like how you expected it to.

While in fedora, I uninstalled kubuntu. I didn't reinstall it, I just deleted it. but then I wondered if it would still show up in the bootloader. so I rebooted, and instead of it going to the grub bootloader, it went straight to windows! Didn't even have to reinstall it. I think the grub bootloader might have already been on kubuntu, and fedora recognized that, so it just added itself to it. so when it was deleted, the bootloader was too. now windows will boot! thank you so much, without you I wouldn't have been able to do this without you.

edit: now that I look at it, fedora was also deleted. not the os, but the bootloader was kind of necessary for it to open. I'm gonna reinstall kubuntu, and not mess with fedora again until I'm dedicating my computer to Linux.

Thank you! 💜

post.body_html:
EDIT: I don't use grub, I use either UEFI or BIOS, I think its bios.

EDIT 2: I checked the other boot options, all 3 of them just bring me to the same thing, the grub bootloader, where I have fedora, fedora advanced (safemode), Ubuntu, Ubuntu avanced (safemode), and 1 of them brings me to an efi shell for my motherboard.

I installed Fedora 33 today, and it worked perfectly! Only problem is that none of my other os's boot up now. to boot i use my motherboard's boot thingy. I had kubuntu and windows installed, but now none of them show up. they're not deleted, I checked, the files are still there, but they won't start. they're all on the same drive, split up by partitions. does anyone know how to fix this?? thank you
post.title: I need help

body: OK, cool. Thought I wonder what a multiboot would be for this.
body_html: OK, cool. Thought I wonder what a multiboot would be for this.

guild.description: All about the Linux operating system.
guild.name: Linux

parent.body:
IT WORKED!! But not like how you expected it to.

While in fedora, I uninstalled kubuntu. I didn't reinstall it, I just deleted it. but then I wondered if it would still show up in the bootloader. so I rebooted, and instead of it going to the grub bootloader, it went straight to windows! Didn't even have to reinstall it. I think the grub bootloader might have already been on kubuntu, and fedora recognized that, so it just added itself to it. so when it was deleted, the bootloader was too. now windows will boot! thank you so much, without you I wouldn't have been able to do this without you.

edit: now that I look at it, fedora was also deleted. not the os, but the bootloader was kind of necessary for it to open. I'm gonna reinstall kubuntu, and not mess with fedora again until I'm dedicating my computer to Linux.

Thank you! 💜
parent.body_html:

While in fedora, I uninstalled kubuntu. I didn't reinstall it, I just deleted it. but then I wondered if it would still show up in the bootloader. so I rebooted, and instead of it going to the grub bootloader, it went straight to windows! Didn't even have to reinstall it. I think the grub bootloader might have already been on kubuntu, and fedora recognized that, so it just added itself to it. so when it was deleted, the bootloader was too. now windows will boot! thank you so much, without you I wouldn't have been able to do this without you.

edit: now that I look at it, fedora was also deleted. not the os, but the bootloader was kind of necessary for it to open. I'm gonna reinstall kubuntu, and not mess with fedora again until I'm dedicating my computer to Linux.

Thank you! 💜
